body: Thanks @himanshug, responded.

Can you put a comment at https://github.com/metamx/druid/blob/cache-connection-per-processing-thread/server/src/main/java/io/druid/client/cache/MemcachedCache.java#L554 that the clients are thread-local, so if there ever are resources to cleanup, making sure the correct client instance does the cleaning would be essential?
@drcrallen the `close(String namespace)` method on the cache is there to invalidate cache items for overshadowed segments and free up memory, the comment is a bit misleading.
@xvrl Gotcha, :+1:  then
lgtm with the additional changes

ugh, works locally fails in travis. Fixing

@zengzhihai110 I believe you can get it via select query http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/select-query.html
Also If you are only interested on Top N values you can use a TopN query.
Travis good, bouncing to verify not a fluke

Spoke with @xvrl about this earlier, but just for the record, what we talked about was that it would probably be better to have a configurable number of cache clients rather than ThreadLocals. Having it be ThreadLocal will probably mean a lot more connections to the cache than we really need or want.

Side note, on the broker the cache checking would potentially sometimes happen in jetty threads and sometimes happen in processing threads. (the IntervalChunkingQueryRunner sometimes uses the processing pool and sometimes doesn't)

@gianm IMHO any sort of processing should be occurring in processing threads, so the number of clients should be controlled via that aspect. If the interval chunking query runner is doing work in a jetty thread then that seems like a bug.

@zengzhihai110 your best bet is a lexicographic topN, which can paginate
through all values of a dimension.

http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/topnmetricspec.html

@drcrallen I still have some doubts about the building. Which is the correct (best-practice?) to build druid with a given extension? So far I build in the following way:

```
mvn install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true
cp -f services/target/druid-services-0.8.2-SNAPSHOT-selfcontained.jar /usr/local/druid/lib
java "-Ddruid.extensions.coordinates=[\"io.druid.extensions:druid-kafka-eight:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT\",\"io.druid.extensions:mysql-metadata-storage:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT\",\"io.druid.extensions:druid-cloudfiles-extensions:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT\"]" -Ddruid.extensions.localRepository=/usr/local/druid/repository "-Ddruid.extensions.remoteRepositories=[\"file:///root/.m2/repository/\",\"http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/\",\"https://metamx.artifactoryonline.com/metamx/pub-libs-releases-local\"]" -cp /usr/local/druid/lib/* io.druid.cli.Main tools pull-deps
cd extensions/cloudfiles-extensions/
mvn dependency:copy-dependencies "-DoutputDirectory=/usr/local/druid/jclouds"
cd ../..
```

and then I run the nodes with the followings:

```
java -Xmx512m -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -cp config/_common:config/coordinator:/usr/local/druid/lib/*:/usr/local/druid/jclouds/* io.druid.cli.Main server coordinator
java -Xmx512m -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -cp config/_common:config/historical:/usr/local/druid/lib/*:/usr/local/druid/jclouds/* io.druid.cli.Main server historical
java -Xmx512m -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -cp config/_common:config/broker:/usr/local/druid/lib/*:/usr/local/druid/jclouds/* io.druid.cli.Main server broker
java -Xmx512m -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -Ddruid.realtime.specFile=config/realtime/kafka_realtime.spec -cp config/_common:config/realtime:/usr/local/druid/lib/*:/usr/local/druid/jclouds/* io.druid.cli.Main server realtime
```

where the properties regarding the extensions in `common.runtime.properties` are:

```
druid.extensions.remoteRepositories=[]
druid.extensions.localRepository=/usr/local/druid/repository
druid.extensions.coordinates=["io.druid.extensions:druid-kafka-eight:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT","io.druid.extensions:mysql-metadata-storage:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT","io.druid.extensions:druid-cloudfiles-extensions:0.8.2-SNAPSHOT"]
```

In this way everythings works fine. But what are the expected steps that are supposed to be performed in order to build druid? I also tried to skip the part where I copy the dependencies of `cloudfiles-extensions`, but all the nodes seems to work fine except for the realtime one which complains about missing providers for jclouds. That's why I add the jclouds dependencies in the runtime classpath. Is there something missing from my side?

Good question. Since the extension is listed in the extension coordinates the best practice is to just mvn clean install in the repository root, then run the services while including the extension coordinates (see the s3 storage  coordinates or mysql metadata coordinates) as the appropriate system property. I can do a short example once not typing on a potato
@drcrallen I'd really appreciate an example!

First you'll want to `mvn clean install`

Your core files are going to be under `distribution/target/druid-0.8.2-SNAPSHOT-bin.tar.gz`

Make a tmp directory somewhere you can extract those to and get them ready:

```
cd $TMP_DIRECTORY
tar -xzvf $DRUID_SRC/druid-0.8.2-SNAPSHOT-bin.tar.gz
cd druid-0.8.2-SNAPSHOT
```

Now you're ready to change the configurations. Add `io.druid.extensions: druid-cloudfiles-extensions` to `druid.extensions.coordinates`. If you're just using the default coordinates then it should look (in `config/_common/common.runtime.properties`) something like

```
druid.extensions.coordinates=["io.druid.extensions:druid-examples","io.druid.extensions:druid-kafka-eight","io.druid.extensions: druid-cloudfiles-extensions"]
```

Then you can run the services as normal. The reason this works is because you `mvn clean install`d locally so the extension finder can find it when it searches through the extension coordinates.

Does that make sense?
Do you think a simple round robin approach (`AtomicLong.incrementAndGet()%maxCapacity`) would be simpler to start with?

@drcrallen we can implement lots of other strategies. I'd like to give this one a shot to reduce contention as much as possible between different cache calls. If the pool itself becomes a bottleneck then we can try simpler things.

ah sorry, I spoke too soon, we actually do it only for the druid processes right now and not for peons
(peons never complained so far, it was mostly an issue at the brokers  time to time)

ok, spoke to @cheddar about storing aggregators in descriptor.json and decided to not put it there as it might increase memory pressure on other nodes... instead have metadata be part of segment metadata query probably and coordinator/overlord or whoever else needs it can query same.

@himanshug, I think @jon-wei can look at that as part of other changes he is working on for the segment metadata query.

One thing I'm wondering is, should the aggregators-merging stuff here be generalized into a general segment metadata merger thing? The segment metadata query has a "merge" flag that causes it to merge individual segment results into a single overall result. It'll need some way of doing the merging for the metadata.drd metadata.

This is "intended" in that tasks have a lifecycle that goes RUNNING -> SUCCESS/FAILED. There is no such thing as a "pending" or "waiting" status. We could change that if we want, but that is why things are the way they are.

@himanshug I don't think storing it in descriptor has to add memory pressure. We can make the data-structures such that we don't have to always keep unnecessary information in memory. Most of the memory pressure, as far as I know is on the coordinator and brokers, which don't need that information. If we load it separately when needed and only keep the minimum for brokers/coordinators it should not be painful.
@gianm not sure if this is beyond the scope of this, but it would also me nice to have actual column byte size and index size information in there.
I think it is beyond scope but that would be a good change.
:+1: But before merging we should decide on the new version of Druid and mysql packaging
@cheddar unless we relicense the mysql metadata store code under GPL, I don't see how packaging it as a separate tarball would make a difference?
Assuming this has been tested, other than my last few comments about docs, and maybe resolve the mysql tabarll issue outside of this PR, I'm :+1:

This is looking good! 

As a note, it is blocked until https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/KXpLwUisJcU/eCM3GfgPBAAJ is resolved
which kinds of metadata do you think should be optional? Do you have anything specific in mind?
@epistemancer there was also a bug with regex extraction on null values #1731
@jon-wei can you describe the scenario in which you see the hydrants going missing?
The estimated size for sure, since it ends up reading a bunch of parts of the columns that otherwise wouldn't need to be read.
But also possibly everything??

@xvrl I ran into an issue where a segment had no hydrants at all, and the empty sink that got created caused an exception later on. This could be due to a corrupted segment that didn't get cleaned up completely because I restarted my druid processes during development.

The hydrant gap handling was to address a potential issue that @gianm mentioned to me, when there are multiple hydrants being persisted in parallel and don't necessarily complete their persist in order.
:+1: as is although I wouldn't complain if the resources were all created up front.
I updated the doc with some thoughts and preliminary code around push-based/tranquility ingestion.
fixes #1750
@gianm addressed all your comments and eagerly instantiated pool upfront.

@drcrallen I'm currently trying your solution. But in this case each machine have to download its own dependencies and I prefer to have _everything_ needed already packaged. In fact the procedure that I posted was inspired by [this](http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/including-extensions.html) and [this](https://github.com/druid-io/docker-druid/blob/master/Dockerfile), but without copying the dependencies with `mvn dependency:copy-dependencies "-DoutputDirectory=/usr/local/druid/jclouds"` it was not working.

I tried your solution.
1. `mvn clean install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true`
2. Unpacked the tar.gz file
3. `cd druid-0.8.2-SNAPSHOT`
4. Edited the `druid.extensions.coordinates` property with `druid.extensions.coordinates=["io.druid.extensions:druid-kafka-eight", "io.druid.extensions:druid-cloudfiles-extensions", "io.druid.extensions:mysql-metadata-storage"]`
5. Start coordinator: `java -Xmx512m -Duser.timezone=UTC -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -cp config/_common:config/coordinator:lib/* io.druid.cli.Main server coordinator`

Then an error occurs:

```
2015-09-18T09:31:36,588 INFO [main] io.druid.initialization.Initialization - Loading extension[io.druid.extensions:druid-cloudfiles-extensions] for class[io.druid.cli.CliCommandCreator]

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException
```

```
cat extensions-repo/io/druid/extensions/druid-cloudfiles-extensions/0.8.2-SNAPSHOT/resolver-status.properties
```

@se7entyse7en During the normal course of deployment the typical workflow is to pull deps to get the dependencies in the correct repository, then package and distribute the complete system. The method described by me above is the easiest for development/debugging that I've found. I'm looking at the error you reported trying to figure out what happened.

Note that extension handling is in active change right now and before you get too far into an automated ops deployment you'll want to be aware of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1638

One major thing to worry about here is multi-value dimensions, and if you want to support inverting non-injective extraction functions.

Ok, by commenting that property all nodes start correctly, but the realtime node complains about missing provider:

```
1) Error in custom provider, java.util.NoSuchElementException: key [rackspace-cloudfiles-us] not in the list of providers or apis: {}
  at io.druid.storage.cloudfiles.CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.getCloudFilesApi(CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.java:85)
  at io.druid.storage.cloudfiles.CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.getCloudFilesApi(CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.java:85)
  while locating org.jclouds.rackspace.cloudfiles.v1.CloudFilesApi
for parameter 0 at io.druid.storage.cloudfiles.CloudFilesDataSegmentPusher.<init>(CloudFilesDataSegmentPusher.java:47)
  while locating io.druid.storage.cloudfiles.CloudFilesDataSegmentPusher
  at io.druid.storage.cloudfiles.CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.configure(CloudFilesStorageDruidModule.java:76)
  while locating io.druid.segment.loading.DataSegmentPusher annotated with @com.google.inject.multibindings.Element(setName=,uniqueId=110, type=MAPBINDER)
  at io.druid.guice.PolyBind.createChoiceWithDefault(PolyBind.java:86)
  while locating io.druid.segment.loading.DataSegmentPusher
```

The only way that I found to solve this is to download all the dependencies through

```
mvn dependency:copy-dependencies "-DoutputDirectory=/usr/local/druid/jclouds"
```

and to add that path in the classpath.

Another concern:

An injective extraction function only need be injective for the domain of the dimension of interest in the query of interest. Injective is a query time property because the extraction function may not be injective for an arbitrary domain. As such, any particular extraction function's injective-ness across the set of all possible Strings is not currently a property of a lookup extraction's underlying data map. (it could be added but would require more data about lookups to be propagated around)

Without this change (or other rule enforcement) it is not possible to simply do a full scan of the range of the lookup transformation and guarantee that only the values of interest will return from the function, but since any values outside the dimension should be eventually ignored, this may not be a problem.

To do a full table scan of the dimension values, apply the lookup transformation, and filter on the values is what the dimension extraction filter currently does. The problem is that it cannot be applied in an optimized way (ex: at the broker) because the broker does not know what the potential dimension values are, it only can get the entire domain of the lookup.

Additionally, the lookup fn has the capacity to either retain or replace missing values, including the capacity to treat missing values as null. Such behavior would have to be preserved when doing an unApply.

From prior conversations I'm assuming the point here is trying to make QTL have the capacity to avoid the full dimension-value scan for pattern matching. Doing so should be possible, but it may have to have very specific constraints on when it can be done.

@se7entyse7en Hmmm, that's a problem. Seems like the pom is missing some dependencies. Would be worth posting links to the pom, branch, and error message to the jclouds user group to see if they have good solutions.
@xvrl looks good other than the two minor comments (unused field and spelling)
:+1: after squash/travis
:+1:  after travis

FWIW, with the changes in #1638 , all the extensions will be automatically packaged within Druid tarball after `mvn clean install`. To make the extension in this PR be packaged, we will need to add an entry at https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1638/files#diff-a55e67b28b0a71de8bca840071b603a9R89
:+1: will merge after travis
@jon-wei there's a few conflicts with the branch
@drcrallen @guobingkun When do you think that #1638 will be merged? Maybe I could wait for that one to be merged and see if it also solves the problem of building this extension.
@se7entyse7en #1638 will be merged after 0.8.2 is released. However, you can do experiment with it now by cherry-picking the commit in #1638, it would be great to have some feedback :)

@himanshug can you provide a bit of context on what the objective is here?

If the objective is to provide a single entrypoint for a UI, I feel we should have a broader discussion on defining one entrypoint for everything, instead of adding more configuration parameters and proxies between nodes.

@drcrallen I don't understand.  Can you be more specific?

At a high level, I think that what we are realizing is that the idea of `ExtractionFn` is a good start for QTL, but it's not sufficient.  For this kind of join, we actually need more functionality and I think it makes a lot of sense to enforce that in the interface in order to unify functionality.  You are correct that the big thing we cannot do without `unapply()` is the broker-level rewrites for filters.

@cheddar Sure,

In the current extractionFn method, the QTL stuff is all represented as a simple map of a set of keys to some values. 

In the current implementation you can have a map as follows:

```
{
  "key1":"value1",
  "key2:"value2",
}
```

Which takes the key# and extracts them to be value#. The most simple case.

The current implementation permits the following functionality:

```
{
  "dim1Key1":"value1",
  "dim1Key2":"value2",
  "dim2Key1":"value1",
  "dim2Key2":"value2"
}
```

For a particular query you may only have dimension values `{"dim1Key1","dim1Key2"}` or `{"dim2Key1","dim2Key2"}` depending on which dimension you are extracting. As such, the individual ExtractionFn which uses the QTL-map can still be injective, since the domain of the dataSource dimension is a subset of the QTL key set. But the total key set for a QTL map (or set of all strings) may not be injective (because there are multiple instances of `value#` in it.

So, if you were to do a simple broker-level rewrite, you could do something like selecting `value1` to mean `dim1Key1 OR dim2Key1`. Which I think would end up being OK because one of the other might never be present.

@cheddar do you have specific use cases that are not covered well by the simple QTL implementation that currently exists? (I believe they exist, but it would help if they are documented explicitly when possible)

@himanshug 
As far as UI interaction goes, most of it already goes through the broker. For that I feel it would make more sense if the proxying happened on the broker / router side. The main reason we proxy overlord from coordinator is because we plan to merge those anyways.

Proxying from the broker side, would also be more natural for people using router as entry-point or multiple brokers, since everything will flow through from those endpoints. We could have a generic implementation that we could reuse interchangeably either at the router or broker level.

As far as segment metadata is concerned, is the broker really necessary? The coordinator can already query segment metadata from the historical nodes directly, it shouldn't need the broker for that.

@drcrallen Thanks for the comments:
So i am not sure i do understand the concerns about having unApply() at the lookup extractor API.
In fact current implementation of lookup is a map based, Hence it is by construction that the unApply function can be built.
As your example shows it is perfectly fine to filter by `dim1Key1 OR dim2Key1` if the filter value is `value1`. 
Is there a case where unApply can't be constructed ?

@xvrl 
1) for the UI, a colleague of mine want to make updates to coordinator console that needs some information from broker endpoints, not sure how to enable that without proxying on coordinator.
2) for coordinator to directly send query to historicals, it has to build the pipeline of query runners , not sure if that is better or worse.
anyways, we can surely discuss the use cases and see what would be the best way to enable them.
Are there any compatibility concerns? (can this version read the older bitmaps? can older versions read these newer bitmaps?)
@gianm I asked the same thing here: https://github.com/metamx/bytebuffer-collections/pull/15#issuecomment-132376385

So it sounds like this version can read older bitmaps, but older versions cannot read the newer bitmaps (because we are going to be writing optimized bitmaps). That sounds OK, since we tell people to update historicals first anyway.

On the [bytebuffer-collections diff](https://github.com/metamx/bytebuffer-collections/pull/15/files#diff-600376dffeb79835ede4a0b285078036R112) I think we should change the roaring version to a specific version rather than a range. Builds with version ranges are not reproducible, and it is good for builds to be reproducible.
@gianm released a new version with fixed dependency
